comment: The Stagg is unbelievably potent and absolutely needs water to keep from killing you. The photo here shows the proof at 137.6 which means it's the 2012 release. 2013 made it up to 142.6, although 2013 dropped down to a surprising 128.2. At any rate it's one amazing Barrel Proof bourbon, and it's baby brother the Stagg Jr. is amazing as well.
Beyond complex.  Add a couple eyedrops of water as you drink to experience the flavors evolve.  Strong caramel and vanilla
Without a doubt the GTS is a man's bourbon .  Chocolate cherry  that makes your mouth water.  Nothing has compared so far this year.
I had the opportunity to try both the 2011 and 2012. While both good, the 2011 had a more complex and rich taste. Very good. Very intense.
This bourbon has such a buttery finish I can't believe it is 142 proof.
Definitely hits you in the face on initial tasting. Flavor opens up with a little water. Would definitely buy a bottle.
hot but well worth it. dark and full on the palate
Good Lord! Called the "velvet jackhammer" in our circles.  Packs a killer punch but smooths out when your tongue numbs.  Nice change when splashed with branch...
The 2012 is the best whiskey I've had the pleasure of drinking.
This  bottle will knock you off your feet! Must add water. Delicious full of flavor but hard to find.

Varies slightly year to year because of the cask strength but you have to luv the in your face power and taste from this whisky. Not as balanced as a William Larue Weller or Pappy but simply delightful.
Top three American whiskeys strong very strong with perfect finishes of Caramel and pepper
The heat and undertones are perfectly balanced
Hot but delicious.  One of the best bourbons around.
Caramel toffee with a smooth burn
Presents hot but full and spicy
The perfection of barrel proof.  Own 2013. Tasted 2012.
One of my favorites! Always need to add just a couple droplets of room temp water though, it's a mouth full of delicious fire.
2oz neat, ice and a sprinkle of distilled water. Amazing!
Yes yes and yes skip the wait list and price tag of pappy 20yr buy 2 bottles of this and add an ice cube

Great bourbon. Notch up from the stagg jr. In the smooth front. But still fire. Got some rich tobacco up front and then some tannins and just classic full on bourbon tone.  Had a ring of charcoal and barrell sediment in the bottom of my glass. Real man shit. A
Smooth, but with flavor. My go to bourbon.
Good lord a lot of heat...but really nice flavors!
Surprisingly smooth given the high alcohol content. Impressive taste ang long finish.
Absolutely a must for your top shelf.  Easy drinking.  Very smoothe.
Aged 15 years, uncut and unfiltered, this is NOT a whiskey for the faint of heart. George T. Stagg is 1/5 of the Buffalo Trace Antique Collection and by far the most aggressive of the lot. Hot
Barrell proof. Sweet and not too hot
Hits you over the head on the first sip and then settles down and shows you just how good and flavorful a premium bourbon can really be.

Nose: Cinnamon, dark cherries, citrus, caramel, cinnamon rolls w frosting, sweet bakery nose, oranges, woody spices, oak barrel, melted butter, cookie dough on the baking sheet, spiced apple cider, creamy buttermilk
Pallet: instant intense woody cinnamon spices, menthol covers pallet, sweet, savory woodiness mid pallet with balls of cinnamon explosion and on the back pallet more spice with apples and charred oak barrel
Finish: french toast w cinnamon, long lingering spices, ground coffee beans, tons of oak, vanilla and robust cigar wrapper.
Definitely water this appropriately. Opens up into a nicely structure oak and caramel.
George T Stagg is a bourbon enthusiasts bourbon. It's big, it's complex, & it's tasty! 2013 release is a winner in my book. 5 stars all the way.
Definitely a full taste, somewhat spicy but doesn't burn. Nice finish

This stuff is amazing. Flavors so rich and full of oak, smoke & brown sugar. || Poured myself an ounce & a half for my birthday last night. I wish I could stock up on this bottle.  Best thing in my bourbon collection.  Pappy Who?
What bourbon should taste like... Harsh neat but really becomes something special with a small I've cube or two
Got a burn...very good though on ice
To each their own.  Try neat, with a cube, or even a few drops of water.

NOSE - SWEET SWEET SWEET. Rich deep dark Honey, Werthers original candies, marshmallows, Nutella 

PALATE - HUGE viscosity, syrupy and sweet, ginger candy, dark honey, praline candied nuts, overwhelmingly amazing! 

FINISH - lime zest, marshmallow sweetness, cinnamon, chocolate hazelnuts 

Some whiskies have no words, BUT incredible, life changing, exhilarating would fit this.

The white whale of the bourbon world beckons.  This is a rare treat for me, and my wife and I had only an ounce of it to share between us.  Thankfully, that was more than enough to savor and enough to do a review.  In the glass, George T. Stagg is a rich, dark chestnut brown, so pure you can practically dry it out and reconstitute the barrel.  One thing I enjoy about Buffalo Trace is that their distillate tends to produce unusual fruit flavors.  Stagg, although much older than the distillery's more commonly found bourbons, is no different.  The standout notes are pineapple, tropical fruit, and raisins, but they meet their match in antique oak, caramel, wood shavings, and tobacco.  We sat around just taking in the scent of this bourbon for a while before having a drink -- it really is that good.  It's hard to describe, and just identifying flavors doesn't convey it, but Stagg's scents are deeper and richer than other bourbons.  The intensity of the alcohol produces a minty or spicy tingle at the beginning, although I believe that's the proof rather than the rye.  The age immediately reveals itself in wood tannins that coat the mouth -- even moreso on subsequent sips.  The only comparable feeling is drinking Elijah Craig Barrel Proof, but even ECBP doesn't have the same sensation of a film over my teeth.  I'm not 100% in love with it, but it's unique.  The midpalate is impossibly rich and sweet, richer than any other bourbon I've tried, and overflows with salted caramel, oak, brown sugar, corn, and cinnamon.  Like the nose, it's hard to convey how intense the flavors are.  Stagg leaves behind a big bomb of ripe banana, spice, caramel corn, mint, apple, and a final lingering note of cedar.  It's a little shorter than ECBP, which features the longest, spiciest finish I've experienced in a bourbon.  Stagg probably is the best bourbon I've had in my life.  However, for most of us, the only realistic avenue to get a bottle is to pay the secondary market price of $500+, and it's not worth that much to me.  It is a unique product, particularly in its rich, complex palate, which is a hair or two better than Elijah Craig Barrel Proof.  But considering I can still find ECBP online or in stores for $60-100, I could never justify paying five to ten times the price for this one.
Fall of 2010 a little more than 1/4 bottle left with one unopened. This was my big score before bourbon blew up and I had $300 to blow on booze.
Recently did a SBS with this and 2014. The 2014 won in a landslide even though I wanted my 2013 to win. The result, I had to go find a 2014 for myself.
Lots of burn. Still average after adding water
This was the best bourbon I've ever had. Went through two bottles and had everyone try it, so I only got a few shots. The gold standard, at least for my palette.
Sweet vanilla nose, spicy punch length

Nose: crisp cherry

Mouthfeel: buttery and a little oily

Palate: subtle that builds into a wave of fire that will take your breath away if you aren’t careful. Rich cherry and fig opens up as you go along 

Finish: strong but becomes more subtle as you acclimate
Way smoother than what the proof is labeled as. Had just enough bite for my liking. Rich in caramel with oak notes
Bourbon drinkers bourbon. Incredibly smooth for high proof. Great taste.
Sweet on the nose, earthy on the palate.
Wow. Awesome. So smooth and easy.
this year was my first tasting the stagg, my best friend and future best man got it for me and it changed my world.
overly sweet to the point I couldnt drink it anymore. extremely disappointing edition. laughable the amount of money people have to pay in the secondary market for this

Sweet nose with no hint of alcohol. A tremendous blend of vanilla, caramel and pepper on the tongue. Very rich. Adding a drop or two of water made no difference. I would drink it at full strength (138 proof).
Amazing. Notes of Vanilla, Caramel, Cherry, Peach, Pepper, Cotton Candy, Dried Fruit, Cinnamon, Pepper, Apple, Pecan, Brown Sugar, Heat, Maple Syrup, and Dark Chocolate Bark.
With just a bit of water this is truly spectacular. One of the best I've ever had.
